raw_text:
Beattie return calms attack fears
 
 Everton striker James Beattie has been declared fit for training on Tuesday, despite suffering an alleged assault last Saturday.
 
 Beattie, 27, is not believed to be as seriously hurt as some reports have suggested after being "the victim of an unprovoked assault" in Birmingham. He was on a night out with his girlfriend and two friends following Everton's 3-1 win over Aston Villa. "He was shaken but not badly injured," said Everton spokesman Ian Ross. He added: "He did speak to the police but will not be pressing charges. "He has spoken to manager David Moyes about what happened." Beattie was suspended for the win at Aston Villa after his red card against Chelsea and he will be available again for the Merseyside derby at Liverpool on 20 March.

He was shaken but not seriously hurt, and is believed to have spoken to police about what happened. He will be available again for the Merseyside derby at Liverpool on 20 March.

Beattie did not pursue legal action and spoke to the police as well as manager David Moyes about the incident. Now available for the Merseyside derby against Liverpool, he was initially suspended after receiving a red card against Chelsea.

James Beattie, 27 years old, has been declared fit following an alleged assault in Birmingham last Saturday. Despite claims of serious injury, Beattie was shaken but not badly injured. Everton's manager has suspended him for a Chelsea incident where he received a red card after a 3-1 win over Aston Villa. He will return to Mersey side derby on March 20 against Liverpool.

Beatty's manager David Moyes believes that he is ready to return to action following the Merseyside derby at Liverpool on March 20th, provided that he remains unharmed during training sessions. Beatty was suspended for the win over Aston Villa and will be available again for Everton's upcoming fixture against Liverpool.
